The City of Corning Wastewater Treatment Facility accidental release prevention program involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, policy, and management practices.  It is in compliance with all EPA Prevention Program and OSHA Process Safety Management Program requirements.  The responsibility of the RMP has been assigned to the WWTP operator who will review the program at least on an annual basis.



Process Safety Information A? The Corning WWTP has developed and maintains written safety information about the chlorination and de-chlorination process and the technology of process equipment used.  The operation of this facility adheres to the guidelines of the Chlorine Institute and to the OSHA regulations regarding Process Safety Management.  Process Safety Information is readily available to all personnel and is updated when changes are made.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) A? A PHA review was conducted in June 2009 appropriate to the complexity of the chlorination process that identified, evaluated, and controlled potential hazards using the A?What-If ChecklistA? and A?Hazard Review ChecklistsA? processes.  These processes include the analysis of hazards due to equipment malfunction and human error.  It describes steps used to detect and monitor releases.  This PHA will be updated every three years (next PHA in June 2012) and the Corning WWTP will conduct reviews whenever major changes occur to the process.

Operating Procedures A? The WWTP plant operator has prepared written standard operating procedures specific to their operations that provide clear instructions for the safe operational activities associated with the process.  These procedures are included in the facility operations manual and the Process Safety Management manual.  The manual includes procedures for operation of all phases of the processes, and normal and emergency shutdown of the process.  These procedures will be reviewed and updated if necessary on an annual basis.  All WWTP

operators have taken a direct role in the development of the operating procedures.



Employee Training: - All existing and newly assigned employees and/or contractors are trained and tested competent in all operation procedures.  Training documentation is maintained on all applicable employees, refresher training is provided quarterly.  The training documentation will be reviewed at least annual to ensure trainings have been completed.



Mechanical Integrity A? The WWTP has a preventive maintenance program (Maintain It A? April 2009) that insures the mechanical integrity of its chlorination / de-chlorination processing equipment, which includes periodic inspection, testing and an annual overhaul of critical processing equipment.  Maintenance procedures are written for each step of the maintenance process and assigned to appropriate personnel.



Management of Change (MOC) A? The WWTP has implemented written MOC procedures to manage changes (except changes in-kind) to process chemical technology, equipment and procedures.  Employees affected by a change in a process are informed of and trained in the change prior to start up of the process or affected part of the process.  Safety information and operation procedures are updated accordingly.



Pre-Startup Review A? Written standard operational procedures have been developed to allow operators to perform a pre-startup safety review for new and modified chlorination equipment, or where modification to the process is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.



Compliance Audits A? A compliance audits was performed in June 2009 and will be performed every three years (next June 2012) to verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed.  The WWTP operators and additional qualified resources will perform the audit.  A report will be developed to summarize the review and findings.  Any recommended actions will be presented to City of Corning for corrective acti

ons.  The two most recent audits will be kept.



Incident Investigation A? The Corning WWTP operators will investigate any incident involving the chemical system which could result or does result in a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas.  The investigation will be conducted within 48 hours of the incident.  All key factors will be addressed and recommendations for correction will result.  Affected personnel will review the findings of the investigation.  The report will be kept for 5 years.



Employee Participation A? The managers and operators of the Corning WWTP participated in the process hazard analysis conducted in May 2009.  The PHA will be made available to all affected employees and is kept at the facilities in the RMP - Process Safety Management binder.



Hot Work Permit A? A hot work permit process has been developed and implemented for hot work operations conducted on or near the chlorination and de-chlorination process.  The permit documents the fire and accident prevention requirements and is implemented prior to beginning any hot work operations.  The permit is kept at the work site until the completion of any hot work.  All completed hot work permits will be retained for at least one year following completion of work.



Contractors A? Contractors working on or near the water treatment plant are required to comply with the regulatory provisions of the OSHA process safety management standard.  A form has been developed to address the following: contractor safety program; informing contractor employees of the hazards on the site; review of the emergency evacuation plans; record contractor meetings of the plans; and require contractors to train their employees on the hazards of the process.  Copies of the forms and documentation are retained in the PSM binder.



Injury and Illness Prevention Program A? The Corning WWTP operators has an active IIPP meeting the requirements of Cal/OSHA Section 3203 that addresses the following;

A?    Assignment of

safety responsibilities

A?    Safety rules and enforcement

A?    Programs designed to gain employee involvement such as safety reward and recognition, safety suggestion incentives and tailgate safety awareness meetings.

A?    An active safety training program to train and educate new and existing employees and contractors on safety related items at the facility

A?    A hazard identification process that includes periodic inspection for safety hazards at the facility

A?    A corrective action program to address deficiencies identified at the facility

A?    Incident and Accident investigation process for all safety related incidents at the facility



Emergency Response Program A? The Corning WWTP has established a working relationship with the City of Corning Fire Department.  Regular meetings are conducted to ensure there is effective interaction and communication with local and state response agencies.  The Tehama County Environmental Management Department, as part of their business plan program, is notified immediately if there is a hazardous material release.  The City of Corning Fire Department will be the incident commander in the case of a chlorine release and will coordinate evacuation procedures in a worst-case scenario.  



The emergency response will depend on the immediate situation as determined by the incident commander.  A list of emergency response scenarios is being developed with the fire department during the periodic meetings.  The major elements of the emergency response plan are:

A?    Upon activation of alarm, notification of all non-essential personnel who are not involved in the emergency response process (visitors, contractors, employees)

A?    Evacuate the facility to a safe location based upon the direction of the air movement

A?    Notify City of Corning Fire Department

A?    Restrict entry to the facility

A?    Establish the Incident Command Structure with Corning Fire Department



The written emergency response plan is provided in the PSM RMP manual.
